Fast.name: Fast
Fast.description: Fast: Barbarians are fast and durable runners. They increase their base Pace by +2. This doesn’t affect their running die, but does stack with Edges like Fleet-Footed or ancestral modifiers.

Favored Enemy.name: Favored Enemy
Favored Enemy.description: Favored Enemy: Rangers study their foes, learning their ways, how to find them, and how to defeat them. Choose a type of enemy from the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08bestiary000000]{Bestiary}. The ranger gets one free reroll when failing to track (Survival) or attack (Athletics (throwing), Fighting, Shooting) that type of being.

Favored Terrain.name: Favored Terrain
Favored Terrain.description: Favored terrain: Choose a terrain type (Arctic, Desert, Forest, Jungle, Plains, Hills/Mountains, Rivers/Seas, Swamp, Urban, or Underground). The ranger draws an additional Action Card for initiative when in his Favored Terrain. (This has no effect on the number of cards a Ranger can use, so a Level Headed character can still choose which card to use, while a Hesitant character must still take the worst card.)

Fear.name: Fear
Fear.description: Particularly frightening monsters cause Fear checks to all who see them. Some truly terrifying monsters may inflict penalties on Fear checks as well. A creature with Fear −2, for instance, causes those who see it to make their Fear checks at −2. See the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04fear0000000000]{Fear} rules for effects.

Fearless.name: Fearless
Fearless.description: Mindless creatures, such as some undead, constructs, and the like, don’t suffer from the weaknesses of the mortal mind. Fearless creatures are immune to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Fear]{Fear} effects and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}. They may still be @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunted}, however (usually because it draws their attention rather than causing emotional distress).

Fey (Bloodline).name: Fey (Bloodline)
Fey (Bloodline).description:
The capricious nature of the fey runs in this sorcerer’s family. She ignores Difficult Terrain in the wilderness and has the “laughing touch.” If she successfully touches a target with her hands (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Touch Attack}), the target is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Distracted}.

  • Advanced Form: Victims of a fey’s spell with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{lingering} effect, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blind]{blind}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{lower trait}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Stun]{stun}, and the like, subtract 2 from any roll made to recover.

Fey (Type).name: Fey (Type)
Fey (Type).description: Supernatural creatures, usually humanoid in appearance, with connections to nature or some other fantastical realm.

Flexibility.name: Flexibility
Flexibility.description: • Flexibility: Half-elves start with a d6 in any one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Attribute} instead of a d4. This does not increase the attribute maximum.

Flight.name: Flight
Flight.description:
The creature can fly at the listed @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace}. It uses its @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} to maneuver in chases or other situations.

If a creature’s Pace is at least 24 and it's flying, attackers subtract 1 when making attacks against it. If it’s Pace is 48 or higher, attackers subtract 2.

Frenzy.name: Frenzy
Frenzy.description: As a limited action, a character with Frenzy may roll a second @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} die with any one of his Fighting attacks for the turn. The extra die may be allocated to the same or different targets as he sees fit. Resolve each separately

Gargantuan.name: Gargantuan
Gargantuan.description:
Gargantuan creatures are those that are at least @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{Size} 12 or higher. They have Heavy Armor (not to be confused with the heavy category of personal armor), can take three additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds}, and their attacks count as @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Heavy Weapons}.

Stomp: A Gargantuan creature may stomp by using an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{area effect} template (the size of the template is determined by the GM based on the monster’s “footprint”). The attack ignores @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} modifiers and is an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{opposed} @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} vs @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Agility} roll (defenders roll individually). Those who can’t get out of the way are stomped for damage equal to the monster’s Strength damage.

Glory (Good, Healing).name: Glory (Good, Healing)
Glory (Good, Healing).description:
• Aspects: Healing, love, mercy, peace
  • Deities: Cayden Cailean, Desna, Erastil, Gorum, Iomedae, Irori, Pharasma, Sarenrae, Shelyn, Torag.
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Arcane Protection]{arcane protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Barrier]{barrier}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Beast Friend]{Beast Friend}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Burst]{burst}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Damage Field]{damage field}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Deflection]{deflection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Fly]{fly}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Growth/Shrink]{growth/shrink}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sloth/Speed]{sloth/speed}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Summon Ally]{summon ally}.

Gnome.name: Gnome
Gnome.description:
Unknown forces drove the gnomes from that realm long ago, forcing them to seek refuge in this world. Despite this, the gnomes have never completely abandoned their fey roots. They are often regarded by other peoples as strange and unpredictable; as a result, gnomes sometimes have difficulty interacting with others even though they bear no particular animosity to anyone.

Gnomes are small; they rarely exceed three feet tall. Their hair tends towards vibrant colors from the fiery orange of autumn leaves to the deep purple of wildflowers. Their facial features vary, although many have large mouths and eyes. Whimsical people, gnomes are known as tricksters who prefer action to inaction.

Languages: Common, Gnome, and Sylvan.

Age Range: Adult 45, old age 150, max age 200-500.

Gnome Males: Height 3'2-3'8 and weight 37-43 (Average 3'5" , 40 lbs).

Gnome Females: Height 3'-3'6" and weight 32-38 (Average 3'3", 35 lbs).

  • GNOME MAGIC: Gnomes can cast @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05cantrips000000]{cantrips} as if they knew each of the following powers:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Light / Darkness]{light}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sound/Silence]{sound}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Telekinesis]{telekinesis}, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Beast Friend]{beast friend} using their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts} (or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{arcane skill} if they have one). They have 1 @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000001]{Power Point} for activating these cantrips, regained as usual (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{here}). Gnomes with an Arcane Background or Mystic Power add their bonus Power Point to their pool but must still learn the spells if they wish to cast them normally.
  • Keen Senses: Gnomes start with a d6 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} instead of a d4. This increases their maximum Notice to d12+1.
  • Low Light Vision: Gnome eyes amplify light. They ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.
  • Obsessive: Gnomes start with a d4 in any one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts}-related skill.
  • Reduced Pace: Decrease the character’s Pace by 1 and reduce the running die by one die type.
  • Size −1: Averaging roughly three and a half feet tall, gnomes reduce their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size} and Toughness by 1.
  • Tough: Gnomes are surprisingly hardy despite their size and strength. They start with a d6 in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Vigor to d12+1.

Gnome Magic.name: Gnome Magic
Gnome Magic.description: • GNOME MAGIC: Gnomes can cast @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05cantrips000000]{cantrips} as if they knew each of the following powers:@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Light / Darkness]{light}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sound/Silence]{sound}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Telekinesis]{telekinesis}, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Beast Friend]{beast friend} using their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts} (or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Spellcasting]{arcane skill} if they have one). They have 1 @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powers00000001]{Power Point} for activating these cantrips, regained as usual (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05activation0000]{here}). Gnomes with an Arcane Background or Mystic Power add their bonus Power Point to their pool but must still learn the spells if they wish to cast them normally.

Grapple.name: Grapple
Grapple.description:
Grappling is an opposed roll between the attacker and defender’s @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}. If the attacker wins, the foe is Entangled. With a raise, he’s Bound. (Success on a foe who was already Entangled makes him Bound.) See @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03boundandenta00]{Bound and Entangled}.

If a foe is Bound, the grappler is also @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03distractedan00]{Vulnerable} while maintaining his hold.

The @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03gangingup00000]{Ganging Up} bonus applies when grappling a defender, but other maneuvers don’t unless the Game Master rules otherwise in a specific situation.

Size Matters: If there’s a difference in Scale (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Size and Scale}) between the attacker and defender, the grappler subtracts the difference from his total (the defender does not).

Creatures may not generally grapple a foe more than two Sizes larger than themselves unless they have exceptional reach or @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} for their Size (GM’s call).

Example: A dragon (Huge +4) tries to pin a half-folk thief (Normal). The difference between Huge and Normal Scales is 4, so the dragon must subtract 4 from its @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll.
If an ogre (Normal) tries to wrestle a great white shark (Large +2), he must subtract 2 from his roll.

Crush: As an action, a grappler may make a Strength roll as damage against a target he has Entangled or Bound. (This is a damage roll so @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Scale} modifiers are ignored.)

Half-Elf.name: Half-Elf
Half-Elf.description:
Half-elves gain the grace of their namesakes, but none of their elegant frailty. Many are well-adjusted progeny of loving unions between a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Human]{human} and an @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Elf]{elf}, but some are shunned by one side of the family or the other. Others may even be mistreated. Hence, a half-elf understands loneliness, and knows that identity is less a product of ancestry than of life experience. As such, half-elves are often open to friendships and alliances with others, and less likely to rely on first impressions.

Their lifespans are closer to their human lineage than those of their elven kin. They exhibit physical characteristics from both their parents, such as pointed ears and human eyes, usually with a pleasing overall effect.

Languages: Common and Elven.

Age Range: Adult 22, old age 93, max age 125-185.

Half-elf Males: Height 5'4-6'6 and weight 110-180 (Average 5'11" , 155 lbs).

Half-elf Females: Height 5'2"-6'4" and weight 100-170 (Average 5'9", 135 lbs).

  • Elven Magic: Half-elves have an inherent connection to arcane energies. They get a free @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{reroll} when rolling to resist enemy powers.
  • Flexibility: Half-elves start with a d6 in any one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Attribute} instead of a d4. This does not increase the attribute maximum.
  • Low Light Vision: Half-elven eyes amplify light. They ignore penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination}.

Half-Orc.name: Half-Orc
Half-Orc.description:
Half-orcs exhibit characteristics of their orc forebears as well as the other branch of their family tree (usually human). They are rarely the result of loving unions, a fact which causes others to distrust and even fear them. Half-orcs are sometimes accepted by orcish communities, but are usually shunned by most others, including @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Human]{humans}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Elf]{elves}, and @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Dwarf]{dwarves}, because of longstanding enmity with their ancestors.

Some half-orcs choose to live among non-orcish peoples, turning their backs on their belligerent roots and looking to redeem themselves. Many are heroic souls trying to prove themselves.

Half-orcs stand between six and seven feet tall, with powerful builds. Their features are harsh and angular, like that of orcs. Their natural life-span is the same as humans, though it is rare when one dies of old age.

Languages: Common and Orc.

Age Range: Adult 15, old age 45, max age 60-80.

Half-orc Males: Height 5'-6'10 and weight 164-318 (Average 5'11", 241 lbs).

Half-orc Females: Height 4'7"-6'5" and weight 124-278 (Average 5'6", 201 lbs).

  • Darkvision: Half-orcs ignore penalties for @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} up to 10” (20 yards).
  • Intimidating: By their very nature, half-orcs inspire fear and awe. They start with a d4 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}. This increases maximum Intimidation to d12+1.
  • Orc Ferocity: Half-orcs are as tough as old boots. They gain +1 Toughness.
  • Outsider (MINOR): Most cultures are suspicious of half-orcs, and orcish societies distrust their human sides. They subtract 2 from all @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} rolls and are often resented or belittled by others.
  • Strong: Half-orcs possess some of the might of their orcish ancestry. They start with a d6 in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Strength} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Strength to d12+1.

Halfling.name: Halfling
Halfling.description:
Halflings are small, nimble people with fuzzy brown or black hair on their heads and feet. Their cheerful optimism (or wily cunning) gives them a “never say die” attitude that makes them a match for creatures twice their size. Halflings see no reason to invite trouble and tend to live in their own close-knit communities far off the beaten path. They possess a strong sense of humor, curiosity, and bravado— qualities which lead some halflings to lives of adventure.

Halflings prefer to walk barefoot, leading to the bottoms of their feet being roughly calloused.

Languages: Common and Halfling.

Age Range: Adult 22, old age 75, max age100-200.

Halfling Males: Height 2'10-3'4 and weight 32-38 (Average 3'1" , 35 lbs).

Halfling Females: Height 2'8"-3'2" and weight 27-33 (Average 2'11", 30 lbs).

  • Agile: Halflings are graceful and agile. They start with a d6 in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Agility} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Agility to d12+1.
  • Keen Senses: Keen senses allow halflings to catch details others might miss. They start with a d6 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Notice to d12+1.
  • Lucky: Halflings have a knack for surviving. They gain the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Luck]{Luck} Edge. Even halfling @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Extras} gain this ability!
  • Reduced Pace: Decrease @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} by 1 and reduce the running die by one die type.
  • Size −1: Halflings reduce their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size} and Toughness by 1.
  • Sure-Footed: Naturally graceful, halflings start with a d6 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Athletics to d12+1.

Hardy.name: Hardy
Hardy.description:
Very tough or determined creatures do not fall from lesser injuries, no matter how many they suffer. A decisive blow is needed to put one of these tenacious creatures down.

If the beast is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, another Shaken result doesn’t cause a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}.

Human.name: Human
Human.description:
Humans possess exceptional drive and ambition. They demonstrate a great capacity to endure hardships, as well as a penchant for expanding their territories. Humanity is often characterized by its tumultuousness and diversity; cultures range from small, nomadic tribes to peaceful agrarian villages and vast cosmopolitan (even decadent) cities and kingdoms.

The physical characteristics of humans are as varied as the world’s climes. From dark-skinned tribesmen of the southern continents to the pale and barbaric raiders of the northern lands, humans possess a wide variety of skin colors, body types, and facial features.

Languages: Common.

Age Range: Adult 17, old age 53, max age 70-110

Human Males: Height 5'-6'6 and weight 130-220 (Average 5'9" , 175 lb).

Human Females: Height 4'7"-6'1" and weight 95-185 (Average 5'4", 140 lb).

  • Adaptability: Humans start with a free @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01edges000000000]{Edge} (they must meet the requirements, as usual). They also gain a d6 in any one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Attribute} instead of a d4. This does not increase the attribute limit.

Humanoid (Type).name: Humanoid (Type)
Humanoid (Type).description: Biped creatures, with a human-like head, torso and limbs. Humanoids usually possess language and form cultures.

Illusion (Favored).name: Illusion (Favored)
Illusion (Favored).description:
Specialists must choose one favored school and two opposition schools from the list @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{here}. They gain a free reroll on arcane skill rolls to cast spells (not activating an item) from their favored school, but spells cast from their opposition school cost one additional Power Point and suffer a −2 penalty to the wizard's arcane skill roll.
Wizards mark opposition spells in their power lists with an asterisk, like this: banish*.

This school deceives the senses or minds of others. These spells often cause people to see things that are not there, or not see things that are. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Disguise]{Disguise}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sound/Silence]{sound/silence}.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{Schools of Magic}

Illusion (Opposition).name: Illusion (Opposition)
Illusion (Opposition).description:
Specialists must choose one favored school and two opposition schools from the list @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{here}. They gain a free reroll on arcane skill rolls to cast spells (not activating an item) from their favored school, but spells cast from their opposition school cost one additional Power Point and suffer a −2 penalty to the wizard's arcane skill roll.
Wizards mark opposition spells in their power lists with an asterisk, like this: banish*.

This school deceives the senses or minds of others. These spells often cause people to see things that are not there, or not see things that are. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Disguise]{Disguise}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sound/Silence]{sound/silence}.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{Schools of Magic}

Immunity.name: Immunity
Immunity.description: Creatures born in fire aren’t affected by heat, and a horror made of pure lightning won’t suffer from a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt} attack with an electrical @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}. Immunities are to specific types of attacks, such as fire, cold, electricity, and so on. Such creatures don’t have @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Invulnerability]{Invulnerability} (see below), they just ignore damage and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stun} results from the specific attack types named.

Improved Frenzy.name: Improved Frenzy
Improved Frenzy.description: As Frenzy but the fighter adds a third Fighting die to his Fighting attack made with Frenzy this turn.

Infection.name: Infection
Infection.description:
A vampire’s bite, a horrid spider-like creature that injects eggs into its victim’s skin, or the scratches of certain vermin might all cause Infection.

A character @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a creature with Infection must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll. Modifiers to the roll are listed in the creature’s description, as are the effects of failure.

Infernal (Bloodline).name: Infernal (Bloodline)
Infernal (Bloodline).description:
A relative made a deal with dark forces in the distant past. The character gains @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Environmental Resistance]{environmental resistance} to fire, immunity to poison, and adds +1 to the damage of any attack powers with a fire @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}.

  • Advanced Form: The infernal grows or hides giant bat wings as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action}. Her wings grant her @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Flight]{Flight} at @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Pace} 12.

Innate Powers.name: Innate Powers
Innate Powers.description:
Various creatures on Golarion have innate powers. These are usually magical abilities with "spell-like" effects or powers.

Unless otherwise noted, activating an innate power is an @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{action} and doesn't require a roll. A minor ability "casts" the listed power with basic success, and a major ability casts as if with a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise}.

If an ability requires a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Trait roll} instead, it's listed after the power (and @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Critical Failure} causes @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Fatigue}). Those that don't require a Trait roll are simply described as minor or major, like so:

  • Innate Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{Invisibility} (@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Spirit}), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{minor puppet}.

Duration: Unless a creature's description lists a particular @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05powermodifie00]{Duration}, Innate Powers may be maintained indefinitely, but terminate instantly if the creature is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}.

Intelligence.name: Intelligence
Intelligence.description: • Intelligence: Elves are highly intelligent and long-lived. They start with a d6 in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Smarts to d12+1.

Intimidating.name: Intimidating
Intimidating.description: • Intimidating: By their very nature, half-orcs inspire fear and awe. They start with a d4 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}. This increases maximum Intimidation to d12+1.

Invulnerability.name: Invulnerability
Invulnerability.description: Invulnerable creatures ignore damage as listed in their description. Unless otherwise specified, they can be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} but not @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by other forms of damage. An ancient dark god given life by misguided cultists, for example, might only be vulnerable to relics of a rival deity.

Iron Constitution.name: Iron Constitution
Iron Constitution.description: • Iron constitution: Dwarves add +1 when resisting @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{poison}. They also add +1 when resisting or recovering from powers or abilities that state they work like a power.

Jump.name: Jump
Jump.description: Characters can jump 1″ (two yards) horizontally, or 0.5″ vertically as a free action. Double these numbers if the hero can run at least 2″ (four yards) prior to the jump. If the hero chooses, she may make an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll as an action to increase her horizontal distance by 1″ (2″ with a raise), or half that vertically. Jumping does not allow a character to exceed her total Pace for the turn.

Keen Senses.name: Keen Senses
Keen Senses.description: • Keen Senses: Gnomes start with a d6 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} instead of a d4. This increases their maximum Notice to d12+1.

Knowledge.name: Knowledge
Knowledge.description:
• Aspects: Literacy, history, revealing secrets
  • Deities: Calistria, Irori, Nethys, Norgorber, Pharasma
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Arcane Protection]{arcane protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Detect/Conceal Arcana]{detect/conceal arcana}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Drain Power Points]{drain power points}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Locate]{locate}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Mind Link]{mind link}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Mind Reading]{mind reading}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Object Reading]{object reading}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Scrying]{scrying}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Speak Language]{speak language}.

Low Light Vision.name: Low Light Vision
Low Light Vision.description: Low Light Vision ignores penalties for Dim and Dark @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} (but not Pitch Darkness).

Luck.name: Luck
Luck.description:
• Aspects: Chance, fortune, losing, winning
  • Deities: Calistria, Desna, Shelyn
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blind]{Blind}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Confusion]{confusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Curse]{curse}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Deflection]{deflection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Disguise]{disguise}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Drain Power Points]{drain power points}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Mind Reading]{mind reading}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Object Reading]{object reading}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{puppet}.

Lucky.name: Lucky
Lucky.description: • Lucky: Halflings have a knack for surviving. They gain the @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Luck]{Luck} Edge. Even halfling @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Extras} gain this ability!

Magic (Rune).name: Magic (Rune)
Magic (Rune).description:
• Aspects: Arcane power, reality, runes
  • Deities: Asmodeus, Irori, Nethys, Urgathoa
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blast]{Blast}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Detect/Conceal Arcana]{detect/conceal arcana}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Elemental Manipulation]{elemental manipulation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Environmental Protection]{environmental protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Havoc]{havoc}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Planar Binding]{planar binding}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Plane Shift]{plane shift}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Scrying]{scrying}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Summon Ally]{summon ally}.

Magical Beast (Type).name: Magical Beast (Type)
Magical Beast (Type).description: Similar to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Animal (Type)]{Animals}, creatures of this type possess some kind of magical or supernatural ability.

Martial Discipline.name: Martial Discipline
Martial Discipline.description: Martial Discipline: Monks hone their bodies to perfection, gaining an additional +1 Toughness if wearing no armor.

Martial Flexibility.name: Martial Flexibility
Martial Flexibility.description: Martial Flexibility: Once per encounter, as a limited free action, a fighter can choose to gain the benefits of a single Combat Edge. He must meet all of the Edge’s Requirements, and the benefits of the chosen Edge end after five rounds.

Mindless.name: Mindless
Mindless.description: This creature is immune to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{Puppet}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt}, and any attempts to manipulate it with any abilities that @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests} its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts}.

Mobility.name: Mobility
Mobility.description: Mobility: Quick and nimble, monks increase their running die by one die type.

Monstrous Humanoid (Type).name: Monstrous Humanoid (Type)
Monstrous Humanoid (Type).description: Similar to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Humanoid (Type)]{Humanoids}, these creatures have some monstrous features or characteristics, as well as magical or beastly abilities.

Natural Healing.name: Natural Healing
Natural Healing.description:
@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounded} characters make a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Vigor} roll every five days. Success recovers one Wounds, and a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise} recovers two.

A @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Critical Failure} increases the victim’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Wounds} level by one—either from infection, blood loss, or aggravating the injuries. If this causes @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Incapacitation}, don’t use the usual rules for taking damage. Instead, the victim lapses in and out of consciousness and makes a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Vigor} roll every 12 hours. If the roll is failed, he expires. Success means he must roll again 12 hours later. With a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise} he stabilizes and wakes. Allies may also attempt to stabilize the hero as explained under Bleeding Out, above.

Support: Don’t forget to use @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03support0000000]{Support} when your party has been beaten up a bit. Characters with @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Healing]{Healing}, @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Survival]{Survival}, or other skills can make Support rolls to help allies make their @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Vigor} rolls to heal!

Natural Weapons.name: Natural Weapons
Natural Weapons.description:
Creatures with natural weapons such as fangs, claws, or horns may attack with any or all of them using their @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} skill. Damage is stated for character races and beasts in their various descriptions.

Creatures with natural weapons are always considered armed. This means they aren’t @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Unarmed Defender} and foes fighting with @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Two Weapons} gain no advantage against them. Here are additional notes for each type of attack:

  • BITE: The creature may bite a target it has grappled (most attackers can only crush their prey, see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling}).
  • CLAWS: +2 to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (climbing) rolls on any rough or soft surface (not sheer steel, glass, etc.).
  • HORNS: Add +4 damage at the end of one @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} action in which it runs, moves at least 5″(10 yards), and successfully hits with its horns.

Nature (Animal, Plant, Weather).name: Nature (Animal, Plant, Weather)
Nature (Animal, Plant, Weather).description:
• Aspects: Animals, plants, weather, seas
  • Deities: Erastil, Gozreh, Rovagug
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Baleful Polymorph]{baleful polymorph}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Barrier]{barrier}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Beast Friend]{Beast Friend}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Burst]{burst}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Elemental Manipulation]{elemental manipulation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Entangle]{entangle}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Environmental Protection]{environmental protection}, protection, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Shape Change]{shape change}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Summon Ally]{summon ally}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Wall Walker]{wall walker}.

Nature Bond.name: Nature Bond
Nature Bond.description:
Nature Bond

The bonds druids form with nature are deep and powerful. Choose one of these abilities:

Attuned: The druid gets one free reroll anytime she fails a Faith roll to activate a spell.

Beast Master: The druid gains the Beast Master Edge, gaining an animal companion. This companion is a Wild Card.

Nature Sense.name: Nature Sense
Nature Sense.description: Nature Sense: Druids commune with nature and its spirits. Survival is linked to Spirit rather than Smarts.

Necromancy (Favored).name: Necromancy (Favored)
Necromancy (Favored).description:
Specialists must choose one favored school and two opposition schools from the list @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{here}. They gain a free reroll on arcane skill rolls to cast spells (not activating an item) from their favored school, but spells cast from their opposition school cost one additional Power Point and suffer a −2 penalty to the wizard's arcane skill roll.
Wizards mark opposition spells in their power lists with an asterisk, like this: banish*.

This school manipulates the power of death, unlife, and the life force. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blind]{Blind}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Curse]{curse}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Drain Power Points]{drain Power Points}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Fear]{fear}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{lower Trait}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Zombie]{zombie}.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{See Schools of Magic for more}.

Necromancy (Opposition).name: Necromancy (Opposition)
Necromancy (Opposition).description:
Specialists must choose one favored school and two opposition schools from the list @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{here}. They gain a free reroll on arcane skill rolls to cast spells (not activating an item) from their favored school, but spells cast from their opposition school cost one additional Power Point and suffer a −2 penalty to the wizard's arcane skill roll.
Wizards mark opposition spells in their power lists with an asterisk, like this: banish*.

This school manipulates the power of death, unlife, and the life force. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blind]{Blind}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Curse]{curse}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Drain Power Points]{drain Power Points}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Fear]{fear}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{lower Trait}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Zombie]{zombie}.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{See Schools of Magic for more}.

Network (The Nice Way).name: Network (The Nice Way)
Network (The Nice Way).description:
Characters use @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} to socialize within their various social circles for information or favors. When used in this way, Persuasion isn’t a single exchange but several hours of networking, hobnobbing, carousing, drinks, gifts, bribes, or entertaining. This might represent time at the office, a series of meetings with important people, or (most commonly) an evening of dinner and drinks.

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Success} grants most of what the character wants, though it may take a while, cost some money, or require a favor in return. A @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise} either gets more of whatever he was looking for, or at a lower cost.

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Failure} means the hero’s efforts are in vain. A @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Critical Failure} means he’s cut off from that particular group for a while (up to the GM but typically about a week). 

Money Talks: You can catch more flies with honey than vinegar, the saying goes. A character with a little lucre to spread around adds +2 to her networking attempt by spending money on better bribes, gifts, or wining and dining her contacts.

The amount required is up to the GM, the setting, and the nature of the contact(s) she interacts with. As a rule of thumb, use the setting’s Starting Funds and modify as appropriate from there.

Network (The Not-So-Nice Way).name: Network (The Not-So-Nice Way)
Network (The Not-So-Nice Way).description:
@Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Intimidation]{Intimidation} can also be used to gather information, call in favors, or make demands, but it’s a little less savory.

Each attempt to “work the streets” takes several hours of threats and general unpleasantness, rousting the local populace for whatever the hero needs.

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Success} grants the character most of what she wants, though her victims might decide to get some payback later on. A @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{raise} means she gets more info, gets it faster, or her victims are too scared or otherwise preoccupied to plot revenge.

@UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Failure} means the goon doesn’t get anything useful. A @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Critical Failure} means she ends the evening with a fat lip, black eye, or broken nose (see @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04bumpsandbrui00]{Bumps & Bruises}). She can work her contacts again the next day, but they’re more likely to be waiting for her this time!

Busting Heads: The bruiser can improve her odds by getting more violent or extreme than usual. This alienates her contacts for a week but adds +2 to the roll.

This raises the stakes as well. A simple failure means the evening ends with @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04bumpsandbrui00]{Bumps & Bruises}, and a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{Critical Failure}  bears more serious consequences. The GM might break the action down to an actual encounter (which might be an ambush!), she might run afoul of the law, come back with two levels of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03fatigue0000000]{Fatigue} from Bumps & Bruises, or her questions might trigger a deadly reaction from a more powerful enemy!

Night Vision.name: Night Vision
Night Vision.description: Some creatures thrive in the darkest depths of the night— or in underground caverns and dungeons. Creatures with night vision ignore all @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Illumination} penalties.

Obsessive.name: Obsessive
Obsessive.description: • Obsessive: Gnomes start with a d4 in any one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Smarts}-related skill.

Ooze (Type).name: Ooze (Type)
Ooze (Type).description: Mindless amorphous creatures, Oozes often consume resources and pose environmental hazards to other creature types.

Orc Ferocity.name: Orc Ferocity
Orc Ferocity.description: • Orc Ferocity: Half-orcs are as tough as old boots. They gain +1 Toughness.

Outsider.name: Outsider
Outsider.description: • Outsider (MINOR): Most cultures are suspicious of half-orcs, and orcish societies distrust their human sides. They subtract 2 from all @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Persuasion]{Persuasion} rolls and are often resented or belittled by others.

Outsider (Type).name: Outsider (Type)
Outsider (Type).description: Although these creatures resemble other types, their origin, or perhaps their composition, comes from beyond the Material Plane.

Pack Tactics.name: Pack Tactics
Pack Tactics.description: This creature applies its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Gang Up} bonus to damage rolls as well as the usual bonus to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}.

Paralysis.name: Paralysis
Paralysis.description: Paralyzing poisons are covered under Poison, below. Other creatures might paralyze their victims with magic, electricity, or other sources. Victims @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a paralyzing effect are @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned} but can't attempt to recover for d4+1 rounds (or longer if otherwise specified).

Plant (Type).name: Plant (Type)
Plant (Type).description: Creatures composed of vegetation, different than regular plant life, which are considered objects.

Poison.name: Poison
Poison.description: Snakes, spiders, and other creatures inject @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04poison00000000]{poisonous} venom via bite or scratch. To do so, the thing must cause at least a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03damageeffect00]{Shaken} result to the victim, who then makes a @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Vigor} roll modified by the strength of the poison (listed in parentheses after the creature’s Poison ability). Effects of failure are described in more detail in the @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{Hazards} section.

Pounce.name: Pounce
Pounce.description: Predators often pounce on their prey to best bring their mass and claws to bear. If a creature with pounce makes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wild Attack}, it adds +4 to its damage instead of +2 to one successful @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting} attack.

Protection.name: Protection
Protection.description:
• Aspects: Protection, care-giving, shelter
  • Deities: Abadar, Nethys, Shelyn, Torag
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Arcane Protection]{arcane protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Barrier]{barrier}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Deflection]{deflection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Detect/Conceal Arcana]{detect/conceal arcana}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Environmental Protection]{environmental protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Intangibility]{intangibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Invisibility]{invisibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Puppet]{puppet}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Summon Ally]{summon ally}.

Push.name: Push
Push.description:
Sometimes characters may want to push a foe in hopes of knocking him out of position, @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03prone000000000]{prone}, or even into a deadly @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor04theadv.JournalEntryPage.04hazards0000000]{hazard}.

Pushing a foe is an @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03traitrolls0000]{opposed roll} of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength}. If the attacker is successful he pushes the foe back up to 1″ (two yards). With a raise, increase the distance to 2″ (four yards). Double either distance if the attacker’s @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Scale} is larger than the foe’s.

A character who’s successfully Pushed must make an @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} roll (at −2 if the attacker got a raise) or be knocked @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03prone000000000]{prone}.

Running: If the attacker ran at least 2″ (four yards) before the Push, he adds +2 to his total.

Size Matters: Creatures may not generally Push a foe more than two @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03sizeandscale00]{Sizes} larger then themselves unless they have exceptional @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} for their Size (GM’s call).

Skill: The attacker or defender may roll @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} instead of @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} if they choose.

Shields: Attackers and defenders add their @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02shields0000000]{shield’s Parry bonus} to their @UUID[Compendium.swade-core-rules.swade-rules.swadecor01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traits00000000]{Strength} (or @Compendium[swade-core-rules.swade-skills.Athletics]{Athletics}) rolls when pushing.

Rage.name: Rage
Rage.description:
Rage: Barbarians can call upon inner reserves of strength and ferocity in desperate circumstances. As a limited free action, a barbarian may “rage” voluntarily. If she’s Shaken or Wounded, she must make a Smarts roll or rage whether she wants to or not.
Rage lasts five rounds. After the barbarian’s fifth turn raging, she takes a level of Fatigue that can only be recovered with an hour’s rest (generally no walking, riding, etc).
An @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Exhausted} barbarian who rages is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated} afterward. See @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{here} for more on Fatigue.

Reduced Pace.name: Reduced Pace
Reduced Pace.description: • Reduced Pace: Decrease the character’s Pace by 1 and reduce the running die by one die type.

Regeneration.name: Regeneration
Regeneration.description:
Hydras, trolls, vampires, and other legendary creatures can Regenerate their injuries.

Regeneration comes in two types: Fast and Slow.

  • Fast: @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} creatures make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll every round— even after they’ve been @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Success} heals one Wound (or removes Incapacitated status), and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} heals an additional Wound. Wounds caused by some types of damage, listed in the creature’s description, do not regenerate but may still heal naturally. Trolls cannot regenerate Wounds caused by flame, for example.
  • Slow: The creature makes a natural @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03healing0000000]{healing} roll once per day.

Rending Attack.name: Rending Attack
Rending Attack.description:
Some creatures have especially vicious claws or weapons. Victims @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken} or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounded} by a rending attack are bleeding and must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action} at the beginning of their next turn.

Failure causes one Wound and the victim must make another Vigor roll next turn. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Success} means the victim doesn't suffer a Wound, but must make a Vigor roll again next turn. A @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} stops the bleeding and no further rolls are required from that attack.

A successful @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Healing]{Healing} roll also stops the bleeding.

Resilient.name: Resilient
Resilient.description:
Some creatures, such as ogres or dire versions of common animals on Golarion, are tough to put down.

Resilient Extras can take one @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound} before they’re @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Incapacitated}, Very Resilient Extras can take two. @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Cards} can’t be Resilient or Very Resilient. The abilities exist to bring select Extras a little closer to the heroes and villains who lead them.

Secret Language.name: Secret Language
Secret Language.description: Secret Language: All druids know the secret language known as druidic.

Sharp Tongued.name: Sharp Tongued
Sharp Tongued.description: Sharp Tongued: Bards may use Performance as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunt} to Test a foe. They may also ignore the Repetition advice given under @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Tests}, as long as they recite different verses, stanzas, lyrics, etc. Bards may also substitute Performance for Taunt to meet Edge Requirements.

Size.name: Size
Size.description:
Size grants a bonus to Toughness (or penalty for small creatures) and is a guide to the typical @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Strength} of creatures in that general range.

Size is generally based on mass, but exceptions exist for extremely large but weak creatures, small but strong beings, etc.

Scale Modifiers are explained under @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size & Scale}.

Additional Wounds: Large creatures can take an additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}, Huge can take two, and Gargantuan three. The maximum Wound penalty is always three. This stacks with @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-abilities.Resilient/Very Resilient]{Resilient/Very Resilient}.

Such creatures typically have @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore02gear00.JournalEntryPage.02gear0000000000]{Reach} equal to the additional @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wounds} granted by Size.

Size -1.name: Size -1
Size -1.description: • Size −1: Halflings reduce their @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Size} and Toughness by 1.

Slender.name: Slender
Slender.description: • Slender: Slight of build and less robust than others, elves suffer −1 Toughness and –1 to @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} rolls.

Smite Evil.name: Smite Evil
Smite Evil.description: Smite Evil: As a free action, a paladin can choose an enemy. If that enemy is evil, she gets a free reroll on any failed @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} rolls against that target for the remainder of the encounter. She may use this ability once per Rank per encounter.

Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
Sneak Attack.description: Sneak Attack: Rogues add an additional d6 to their damage when they have the Drop on their victim, or the victim is Vulnerable. This applies to @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} (throwing), @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, or @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting} attacks.

Spellbooks.name: Spellbooks
Spellbooks.description:
Spellbooks: Wizards must keep and maintain spellbooks.

Spellbooks

@Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-gear.Spellbook, Wizard (blank)]{Link to Journal Entry}

Wizard spells are strange, complex things that fade quickly from the minds of even the most accomplished casters. For this reason, each wizard maintains a spellbook with the spells he’s translated and acquired. He studies them daily, transcribing their mystical patterns onto his mind.

The link to the book is far more than rote memorization— it is an arcane bond with the power and patterns within. If a wizard doesn’t have access to his spellbook, he may continue to cast normally until the next sunset or sunrise (whichever comes first). After that, the magical imprint on his mind fades and he can no longer cast them.

Wizards may only carry one active spellbook at a time. The mountains of scrolls, magical notations, and research needed to prepare another cannot be carried with the wizard and must be stored safely somewhere. It takes a week of work and 500 gp to create a replacement spellbook once the wizard has access to his magical notes.

When a wizard takes the New Powers Edge, he chooses any two powers as usual. If he has found any spells (including scrolls) through exploration or purchase, and it is of his Rank or less, he may take one of those as a bonus third power at that time as well

Stone Cunning.name: Stone Cunning
Stone Cunning.description: • Stonecunning: Dwarves grow up in halls and caverns of worked stone, and get a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Notice]{Notice} roll at +2 as a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{free action} within 10 feet of unusual stonework such as traps and hidden doors. Success means they know something is off, and a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{raise} gives them more specific information such as how to trigger the trap or open the door.

Strength.name: Strength
Strength.description:
• Aspects: Brawn, champions, contest
  • Deities: Cayden Cailean, Gorum, Irori, Lamashtu, Urgathoa
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Arcane Protection]{arcane protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Burrow]{burrow}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Drain Power Points]{drain power points}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Growth/Shrink]{growth/shrink}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Havoc]{havoc}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sloth/Speed]{sloth/speed}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Stun]{stun}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Wall Walker]{wall walker}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Warrior's Gift]{warrior's gift}.

Strong.name: Strong
Strong.description: • Strong: Half-orcs possess some of the might of their orcish ancestry. They start with a d6 in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Strength} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Strength to d12+1.

Stun.name: Stun
Stun.description: A creature with this ability often has an electrical attack, mild toxin, mind lash, or similar @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05trappings00000]{Trapping}. When it successfully hits a character (even if it causes no damage), she must make a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} roll minus any listed penalties or be @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Stunned}.

Stunning Fist.name: Stunning Fist
Stunning Fist.description: STUNNING FIST: When a monk hits a target with an Unarmed Strike and scores a raise, he may make the foe Distracted or Vulnerable. This occurs even if the victim takes no damage or Soaks it (the states are applied after the victim attempts to Soak).

Sun.name: Sun
Sun.description:
• Aspects: Light, radiance, warmth, life
  • Deities: Iomedae, Sarenrae
  • Available Powers: @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Blind]{Blind}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Bolt]{bolt}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Confusion]{confusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Damage Field]{damage field}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Drain Power Points]{drain power points}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Environmental Protection]{environmental protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Fly]{fly}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Illusion]{illusion}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Protection]{protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Stun]{stun}.

Sure-Footed.name: Sure-Footed
Sure-Footed.description: • Sure-Footed: Naturally graceful, halflings start with a d6 in @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Athletics]{Athletics} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Athletics to d12+1.

Swallow Whole.name: Swallow Whole
Swallow Whole.description: Certain massive creatures with gigantic maws can swallow their prey whole. This usually requires a successful @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Bite} attack. See the creature’s description for details and how prey might escape this dire fate!

Swat.name: Swat
Swat.description: The creature has learned how to deal with pesky creatures smaller than itself. It ignores up 4 points of @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Scale} penalties when attacking with certain abilities listed in its description (and only those specific abilities).

Tentacles.name: Tentacles
Tentacles.description:
The creature has a number of “tentacle actions” specified in its description (usually 2 or 4) it may use once per turn. All of a creature's tentacle @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{actions} count as one of its three potential actions for the turn, and must stem from the tentacle in some way— usually a @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Fighting]{Fighting}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Shooting]{Shooting}, or @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling} attack (GM’s call). A giant octopus with four tentacle actions, for example, could make four attacks as one action and still have two actions left over.

If the creature is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Card}, it rolls its @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03rules000000000]{Wild Die} with each tentacle action as usual.

If the being performs other actions on its turn, such as @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-skills.Taunt]{Taunting} or casting a spell, these and the tentacle actions are affected by the @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Multi-Action} penalty as usual.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03situationalr00]{Grappling} rolls made with tentacles get a +2 bonus, and its crushing attack causes the creature’s @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Strength} in damage unless otherwise listed.

Severing a tentacle is a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Called Shot}. If damage exceeds the creature’s Toughness, the limb is severed and the monster is @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}. If it was already @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Shaken}, it takes a @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Wound}.

Tough.name: Tough
Tough.description: • Tough: Gnomes are surprisingly hardy despite their size and strength. They start with a d6 in @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore01charac.JournalEntryPage.01traitsummari00]{Vigor} instead of a d4. This increases maximum Vigor to d12+1.

Trample.name: Trample
Trample.description:
Elephants, rhinoceroses, and other large creatures can trample smaller victims under foot when moving at least 5″ (10 yards) in a straight line. This usually applies only when the opponents are at least two @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore08bestia.JournalEntryPage.08sizetable00000]{sizes} smaller. See the creature's description for any special conditions or effects.

The creature makes a single attack at −2 and applies it to all victims in its movement path. Those it tramples may make an attack on it after if passes if desired (see @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore03rules0.JournalEntryPage.03combat00000000]{Withdrawing From Melee}), unless it has @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-edges.Extraction]{Extraction} or a similar ability.

Transmutation (Favored).name: Transmutation (Favored)
Transmutation (Favored).description:
Specialists must choose one favored school and two opposition schools from the list @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{here}. They gain a free reroll on arcane skill rolls to cast spells (not activating an item) from their favored school, but spells cast from their opposition school cost one additional Power Point and suffer a −2 penalty to the wizard's arcane skill roll.
Wizards mark opposition spells in their power lists with an asterisk, like this: banish*.

Transmutation changes the properties of some creature, thing, or condition. @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Boost/Lower Trait]{boost Trait}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Darksight]{darksight}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Elemental Manipulation]{elemental manipulation}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Entangle]{entangle}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Environmental Protection]{environmental protection}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Farsight]{farsight}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Fly]{fly}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Growth/Shrink]{growth/shrink}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Intangibility]{intangibility}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Shape Change]{shape change}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Sloth/Speed]{sloth/speed}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Smite]{smite}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Telekinesis]{telekinesis}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Time Stop]{time stop}, @Compendium[swpf-core-rules.swpf-powers.Wall Walker]{wall walker}.

@UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{See Schools of Magic for more}.

Transmutation (Opposition).name: Transmutation (Opposition)
Transmutation (Opposition).description:
Specialists must choose one favored school and two opposition schools from the list @UUID[Compendium.swpf-core-rules.swpf-rules.swpfcore05powers.JournalEntryPage.05schoolsofmag00]{here}. Wizards mark opposition spells in their power lists with an asterisk, like this: banish*.
